FWIW, the result of the discussion cited by David is that NUnit was changed=
 
to conform to alternative 2 below. We didn't follow alternative 3, becaus=
e that
requires an extra test in many cases.

I also added an Assert.IsNaN(=
 double ), which is much clearer when the
expected value is known to be NaN=
 at compile time.

Charlie

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yaho=
ogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of
> David Saff
> Sent:=
 Thursday, October 20, 2005 8:21 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: =
Re: [junit] JUnit 4 issue: NaN handling
> 
> 
> This was discussed in the c=
ontext of NUnit starting at:
> 
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/testdrivend=
evelopment/message/11579
> 
> My biased summary:
> 
> 1) The current behavi=
or of JUnit, in which assertEquals(Double.NaN, x) 
> always fails as unequa=
l, is confusing and unhelpful.
> 2) Ron Jeffries favored special-casing NaN=
 so that 
> assertEquals(Double.NaN, Double.NaN, 0.1); passes.
> 3) I propo=
sed having assertEquals(Double.NaN, x) always fail with a 
> failure messag=
e ("Asserting equality with NaN is meaningless.  Please 
> use assertIsNaN"=
).
> 
> I think 2 or 3 is fine.
> 
>     David Saff
> 
> Elliotte Harold wr=
ote:
> 
> > I think the handling of NaN by assertEquals(double, double, dou=
ble) and
> > assertEquals(float, float, float)  should be thought out and m=
ore
> > carefully spelled out. For instance, the following assert fails:
> =
>
> >    assertEquals(Double.NaN, Double.NaN, 0.1);
> >
> > i.e. NaN is not=
 equal to NaN. I'm honestly not sure whether this is
> > correct or not. Wh=
at does the principle of least surprise suggest? If
> > someone understands=
 NaN they may find this correct but someone who's not
> > intimately famili=
ar with NaN may be surprised.
> >
> > This edge case does have practical co=
nsequences. For one, the Apache
> > Commons Math project has found it neces=
sary to create their own double
> > assertEquals methods that do consider N=
aN to be equal to NaN. See
> >
> > 
> http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/jak=
arta/commons/proper/math/trun
> k/src/test/org/apache/commons/math/TestUtil=
s.java?rev=3D240245&view=3Dmarkup 
> > 
> <http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cg=
i/jakarta/commons/proper/math/tru
> nk/src/test/org/apache/commons/math/Tes=
tUtils.java?rev=3D240245&view=3Dmarkup>
> >
> > I could go either way on th=
is. However, I do think it's important that a
> > definite decision about h=
ow to handle NaN be made, and that the result
> > of this decision be spell=
ed out in the JavaDoc. Currently Infinity is
> > addressed but not NaN, and=
 NaN is by far the more confusing case.
> >
> > It probably also wouldn't h=
urt to patch the JUnit 3 JavaDoc at least
> > enough to document the curren=
t behavior, whatever that is.
> >
> > --
